awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Secondary Production of Ice in CUmuLus Experiment (SPICULE)
awd_abstract_narration:
Clouds can contain liquid droplets, frozen crystals, or a mixture of both.  Whether a cloud is mostly liquid or mostly frozen has a significant impact on the potential for precipitation and the interaction of the cloud with radiation.  Certain clouds can change from mostly liquid to entirely frozen in a surprisingly short amount of time, a phenomenon known as glaciation.  The speed at which clouds glaciate is dependent on the phenomena of secondary ice production, where the freezing of some droplets affects others in a cascading fashion.  The exact mechanism for efficient secondary ice production is still up for debate in the scientific community.  This project will consist of two research aircraft making measurements of the same cloud at different heights to provide additional data on secondary ice production.  The main societal impact of the award will be through the improvement of the representation of ice processes in numerical weather models, leading to better weather forecasts and climate projections.  Student involvement will ensure the education and training of the next generation of scientists.

The research team will conduct a summer 2020 field campaign in the western Great Plains to improve understanding of the processes involved in ice initiation and secondary ice production in cumulus clouds.  The investigators argue that the well-known Hallet-Mossup process is not able to explain the observed rapid glaciation of cumulus clouds, and they offer the alternative hypothesis that the development of supercooled liquid droplets at the -5C level in strong cumulus updrafts leads to a spicule production/drop fracturing secondary ice production and rapid glaciation by the -20C level.  The study is designed to provide improved quantitative measurements with dedicated flight profiles that will minimize ambiguity associated with primary nucleation and contamination from older clouds.  The NSF/National Center for Atmospheric Research C-130 aircraft would target the below cloud region through the 0C level and the SPEC LearJet would penetrate the cloud from the 0C level and up in altitude.  Important instruments include the Colorado State University suite of ice nuclei probes, the SPEC 3V-CPI and the University of Wyoming W-band cloud radar.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Ice nucleation by aerosol particles is the trigger for precipitation formation in many deeper convective clouds around the world. Incomplete understanding of ice initiation processes in clouds results in large uncertainties in the ability to model clouds and precipitation. This is largely due to an incomplete knowledge of how ice formation evolves initially due to primary ice nucleation on aerosols, which then stimulates secondary ice formation processes that dominate as clouds mature. The Secondary Production of Ice in CUmuLus Experiment (SPICULE) conducted airborne measurements in developing convective clouds over the west-central U.S. High Plains based around a major hypothesis that the development of supercooled large droplets rising into regions below 0 degrees C in strong cumulus cloud updrafts leads to a fragmentation of freezing droplet mechanism of secondary ice production and rapid glaciation of clouds by the -20 degrees C level. This contrasts with previous belief that secondary ice formed mainly via ice splinter production when larger ice particles freeze colliding cloud droplets in the -3 to -8 degrees C regime. Unique for SPICULE in comparison to most other studies over continental regions in the last 40 years was the incorporation of an end-to-end approach to documenting both primary and secondary ice formation processes via measurements of ice nucleating particles and cloud measurements documenting ice formation. This included documenting cloud base aerosol and liquid cloud properties supporting the occurrence of coalescence formation of supercooled liquid droplets, use of new technology cloud probes to identify the occurrence of ice morphologies associated with different secondary ice production processes, relational analyses of ice formation to cloud updrafts, age and temperature structure, the supporting use of cloud Doppler radar, direct measurements of ice nucleation on aerosols below-cloud and from the residues of cloud particles within cloud, and the supporting use of cloud modeling. This grant supported PhD studies revolving around direct ice nucleation measurements, analyses of in situ cloud probe data to document occurrence or not of secondary ice production versus primary ice nucleation in growing young clouds, and the use of idealized numerical model simulations to implement and explore the role of secondary ice production compared to observations.

The following outcomes represent the major intellectual merit of this project: 1)The spatial distribution of ice nucleating particles over the central U.S. High Plains was determined during the late Spring start of the convective precipitation period, the first data of its type collected in nearly 40 years; 2) observations in the tops of growing cumuli corroborated other recent studies in finding that a deep cloud region >0 degrees C and more vigorous cloud updrafts promote the formation of larger supercooled droplets and stimulation of secondary ice formation at temperatures primarily below -10 degrees C; 3) higher aerosol concentrations may have promoted smaller and more numerous cloud droplets and could have suppressed  such secondary ice formation, but were far less important than warm cloud depth and updraft strength; 4) the observed absence of ice concentrations exceeding those predicted by measured ice nucleating particle concentrations and low frequency of needle-like or growing columnar crystals at cloud temperatures > ‑10 degrees C do not support the dominance of splinter production by droplets accreting onto crystals in young updrafts; 5) idealized cloud-resolving model simulations of a convective storm, constrained by meteorological and aerosol profile data, produced ice in close correspondence with observations for cases where secondary ice processes were not deemed to have ensued; and 6) a simulation including mechanistic descriptions of secondary ice formation processes produced ice concentrations in the same range as for observed cases of secondary ice formation, but this result was driven primarily by the droplet accretion/splinter mechanism and with only minor contributions from large droplet freezing or other processes. The model discrepancy with observations has a variety of potential sources including the timing of downdrafts that bring larger ice particles to lower levels that mix into new updrafts to feed the splintering process, and the possibility that the model is both overpredicting the (uncertain) number of splinters formed via accretion/splintering and underpredicting the number of fragments from large droplet freezing. Future lab and field observations could help resolve appropriate parameters to use for these secondary ice formation processes. Also, only a single model cumulus cloud initialization was used as representative of observations, meaning that many sensitivity studies remain to be explored in the future.

The broader impacts of this research included training of graduate studenta, onw of qhom based his PhD dissertation on the results from this study, broad collaboration with graduate students and researchers from collaborator institutes, and media coverage of this work. The SPICULE data base is likely to remain a significant global research community resource for many years.
